data:
This feature is only available in the docs theme.
Nextra supports Next.js Internationalized Routing out of the box.To add multi-language pages to your Nextra application, just need to config i18n in next.config.js:
const withNextra = require('nextra')('nextra-theme-docs', './theme.config.js')

module.exports = withNextra({
i18n: {
locales: ['en', 'zh', 'de'],
defaultLocale: 'en'
}
})
Then, add the locale codes to your file extensions (required for the default locale too):
/pages
index.en.md
index.zh.md
index.de.md
meta.en.json
meta.zh.json
meta.de.json
...
Finally, add the i18n option to your theme.config.js to configure the language dropdown:
i18n: [
{ locale: 'en', text: 'English' },
{ locale: 'zh', text: '‰∏≠Êñá' },
{ locale: 'de', text: 'Deutsch' },
{ locale: 'ar', text: 'ÿßŸÑÿπÿ±ÿ®Ÿäÿ©', direction: 'rtl' }
]

You can use Next.js Image directly in MDX.If the demo.png file is located at /public/demo.png, you can use the code below to display it:
import Image from 'next/image'

<Image src="/demo.png" alt="Hello" width={500} height={500} />
data.static-image#Static Image:
You need to opt-in to this feature by enabling staticImage:
true.
Nextra also supports automatic static image imports, you no longer need to specify the width and height of the image manually,
and you can directly use the Markdown syntax to display the same image:
![Hello](/demo.png)
With Next.js Image, there will be no layout shift, and a beautiful blury placeholder will be shown by default when loading the images:

data:
Nextra uses KaTeX to render LaTeX expressions directly in MDX.
To enable LaTeX support, you must add the following to your next.config.js:
module.exports = require('nextra')({
latex: true
})
Using LaTeX within MDX is as simple as wrapping your expression in $$ or $. For example, the following code
$\sqrt{a^2 + b^2}$
will be rendered as: To learn more about KaTeX and its supported functions, visit their documentation.

/features/mdx.title: Hello, This Is a Title Inside h1

data:
With Nextra, all your .md and .mdx files under the pages directory will be rendered with MDX, it's an
advanced Markdown format with React component support.You can use import and use React components inside your Markdown files like this:
import { Callout } from 'nextra-theme-docs'

**Markdown With React Components**

<Callout emoji="‚úÖ">
**MDX** (the library), at its core, transforms MDX (the syntax) to JSX. It
receives an MDX string and outputs a _JSX string_. It does this by parsing the
MDX document to a syntax tree and then generates a JSX document from that
tree.
</Callout>
Generates:
Markdown With React Components
MDX (the library), at its core, transforms MDX (the syntax) to JSX. It
receives an MDX string and outputs a JSX string. It does this by parsing the
MDX document to a syntax tree and then generates a JSX document from that
tree.

Nested quotes:

Where some people measure progress in answers-right per test or tests-passed per year, we are more interested in Sistine-Chapel-Ceilings per Lifetime.‚Äî Alan Kay, A Personal Computer for Children of All Ages
This is great.‚Äî Shu Ding.

data.react-components#React Components:
React components and Markdown can be mixed together, for instance:
<Callout>Give [**Nextra**](https://github.com/shuding/nextra) a star!</Callout>
Renders:

Give Nextra a star!

data:
Nextra itself is basically a plugin that normalizes your Markdown routes in Next.js into structural data, and it doesn't handle any styling related thing. A theme is what renders your actual pages, it works like a layout component in React.Nextra has 2 official themes that you can use:
Docs Theme
Blog Theme

You can also extend your own themes. Here's a great starter example by @jaredpalmer:
Nextra Blank Custom Theme/Boilerplate Example

data.quick-start-with-vercel#Quick Start with:
You can start by creating your own Nextra site and deploying to Vercel by clicking the link:Vercel will create the Nextra repository and deploy the site for you with just a few clicks.
Once done, every change in the repository will be deployed automatically.
data.create-manually#Create Manually: Nextra works like a Next.js plugin, and it accepts a theme config (layout) to render the page. To start: Install Next.js, Nextra and React npm i react react-dom next nextra yarn add react react-dom next nextra pnpm i react react-dom next nextra Install the docs theme npm i nextra-theme-docs yarn add nextra-theme-docs pnpm i nextra-theme-docs Create the following Next.js config and theme config under the root directory: const withNextra = require('nextra')({ theme: 'nextra-theme-blog', themeConfig: './theme.config.js' // optional: add `staticImage: true` to enable Nextra's auto image import }) module.exports = withNextra() Create a theme.config.js file for the docs theme: /** * @type {import('nextra-theme-docs').DocsThemeConfig} */ export default { project:{ link: 'https://github.com/shuding/nextra' // GitHub link in the navbar }, docsRepositoryBase: 'https://github.com/shuding/nextra/blob/master', // base URL for the docs repository getNextSeoProps: () => ({ titleTemplate: '%s ‚Äì Nextra' }), navigation: true, darkMode: true, footer: { text: `MIT ${new Date().getFullYear()} ¬© Shu Ding.` }, editLink: { text: 'Edit this page on GitHub' }, logo: ( <> Next.js Static Site Generator ), head: ( <> ), primaryHue: { dark: 204, light: 212 } } More configuration options for the docs theme can be found here. You are good to go! Run yarn next to start. Any .md or .mdx file will turn into a doc page and be displayed in sidebar. You can also create a meta.json file to customize the page order and title. Check the source code: https://github.com/shuding/nextra for more information. You can also use

data.development#Development:
Use Gitpod, a free online dev environment for GitHub.
Or clone locally:
$ git clone https://github.com/xirosoft/bee-ui.git
$ cd bee-ui
$ npm install
$ npm watch
data.folder-structure-of-bee-ui#Folder Struct:
.
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ dist/                       # Compiled files
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ components/             # Compiled Components
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/                       # Documentation
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ src/                        # Source
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ builds/                 #
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/             # Components
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ internal/               # Function, mixin, theme...
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ utils/                  # SCSS Utils styles
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bee-all.scss            #
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ bee-core.scss           #

here.
Similar to the docs theme, you can install the blog theme with the following commands:
A built-in component provided by nextra-theme-docs.
data.example#Example:
When wrapping your content with <Bleed>, it will be slightly wider than the container
and will overflow on both sides.

There is nothing to writing. All you do is sit down at a typewriter and bleed.‚Äî Ernest Hemingway

It provides a better reading experience when you want to present some graphical information, which normally
looks nicer in a larger size.For example you can put text, image, video or any component inside:



You can even make it full-bleed using <Bleed full>:
data.mdx-component#MDX component:
<Bleed>Hey, I can use **Markdown** syntax here.</Bleed>

</Bleed>

title="SWR-States"
/>
</Bleed>

data.head#head:
The head that should be inserted into the html document.Type: ReactNode | React.FC<PropsWithChildren<{ locale: string; config: DocsThemeConfig; title: string; meta: Record<string, any> }>>{:ts}Example:
/**
* @type {import('nextra-theme-docs').DocsThemeConfig}
*/
export default {
head: ({ locale, title, config, meta }) => (
<>
<meta name="msapplication-TileColor" content="#ffffff" />
<meta name="theme-color" content="#ffffff" />
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
<meta httpEquiv="Content-Language" content="en" />
<meta name="description" content="Nextra: the next docs builder" />
<meta name="twitter:card" content="summary_large_image" />
<meta name="twitter:site" content="@shuding_" />
<meta property="og:title" content="Nextra: the next docs builder" />
<meta property="og:description" content="Nextra: the next docs builder" />
<meta name="apple-mobile-web-app-title" content="Nextra" />
</>
)
}
data.i18n#i18n: The internationalization (i18n) config. See more here.

data:
This website is built with the docs theme.
you can install the blog theme with the following commands:
data.getting-start#Getting start: Install Next.js, Nextra and React npm i react react-dom next nextra yarn add react react-dom next nextra pnpm i react react-dom next nextra Install the docs theme npm i nextra-theme-docs yarn add nextra-theme-docs pnpm i nextra-theme-docs Create the following Next.js config and theme config under the root directory: const withNextra = require('nextra')({ theme: 'nextra-theme-blog', themeConfig: './theme.config.js' // optional: add `staticImage: true` to enable Nextra's auto image import }) module.exports = withNextra() /** * @type {import('nextra-theme-docs').DocsThemeConfig} */ export default { projectLink: 'https://github.com/shuding/nextra', // GitHub link in the navbar docsRepositoryBase: 'https://github.com/shuding/nextra/blob/master', // base URL for the docs repository titleSuffix: ' ‚Äì Nextra', nextLinks: true, prevLinks: true, search: true, customSearch: null, // customizable, you can use algolia for example darkMode: true, footer: true, footerText: `MIT ${new Date().getFullYear()} ¬© Shu Ding.`, footerEditLink: `Edit this page on GitHub`, logo: ( <> Next.js Static Site Generator ), head: ( <> ) } Create pages/_app.js and include the theme stylesheet: import 'nextra-theme-docs/style.css' export default function Nextra({ Component, pageProps }) { const getLayout = Component.getLayout || (page => page) return } You are good to go! You can also use

data: A built-in component provided by nextra-theme-docs.
data.mdx-component#MDX component:
<Tabs items={['JavaScript', 'C++', {label:'C', disabled: true}, 'Python']} defaultIndex={1}>
<Tab>
```js filename="hi.js"
import { useState, useEffect } from 'react';
```
</Tab>
<Tab>
```cpp filename="hi.cpp"
#include <iostream>
```
</Tab>
<Tab>
```c filename="hi.c"
#include <stdio.h>
```
</Tab>
<Tab>
```python filename="hello.py"
print('Hello, world!')
```
</Tab>
</Tabs>
data.react-component#React Component:
import { Tabs, Tab } from 'nextra-theme-docs'
const items = ['1', '2', '3', '4']
const defaultIndex = 1
const Component = () => (
<Tabs items={items} defaultIndex={defaultIndex}>
<Tabs.Tab>1</Tab>
<Tabs.Tab>2</Tab>
<Tabs.Tab>3</Tab>
<Tabs.Tab>4</Tab>
</Tabs>
)
export default Component
